conclusion: Analyzing the thermodynamic process shown in the diagrams
V-T diagram showing the relationship between volume and temperature for an ideal gas
Point A is at coordinates (T₀, V₀)
Point B is at coordinates (T₀, 2V₀)
Line segment AB is parallel to the V axis (meaning temperature is constant)
Line BC passes through the origin when extended
The work done by the gas during process A→B is 10 J
Find the heat absorbed by the gas during process A→B
Process A→B is an isothermal process since the temperature remains constant at T₀
During an isothermal process for an ideal gas, PV = constant
First law of thermodynamics: Q = ΔU + W
Q is the heat absorbed by the gas, ΔU is the change in internal energy, W is the work done by the gas
For an ideal gas, the internal energy U depends only on temperature
Since the temperature doesn't change during process A→B, ΔU = 0
Therefore, Q = W = 10 J
Verification using ideal gas properties
For an isothermal process, PV = constant
PA = p₀ and VA = V₀
At point B, VB = 2V₀
Since PV = constant, PB = p₀ × (V₀/2V₀) = p₀/2
The work done in an isothermal process is W = nRT ln(V₂/V₁)
W = nRT₀ ln(2V₀/V₀) = nRT₀ ln(2) = 10 J
Since the process is isothermal, all the work done by the gas (10 J) must come from heat absorbed from the surroundings
